results.title: Language (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Glen Howard, Harper & Row and State Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Development of the Child”.
Examines the child’s language process in the first four years, beginning with the development of phonemes, semantics and syntax. Looks at the process by which language is acquired and how that acquisition can be influenced.

results.title: Cognition (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Glen Howard, Richard L. Berman, Bay State Film Productions and Harper & Row
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Development of the Child”.
Examines developmental changes in perception, memory, evaluation and reasoning. Includes Piaget’s description of the major stages of development and intelligence and discusses the relevance of attention to detail, recognition and recall memory, conservation of mass and number, and reasoning evaluation.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Glen Howard, Richard L. Berman, Bay State Film Productions and Harper & Row

results.title: Cross cultural approach to acquisition of sex roles and social standards (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Glen Howard, Bay State Film Productions, Harper & Row and Jerome Kagan
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Development of the Child”.
The culturally diverse settings of Guatemala, Kenya and Japan focus on the basic mechanisms by which social standards and sex role orientations are acquired. Children are shown learning by the mechanisms of observation, imitation, praise and punishment.

results.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788
results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Who'll do the dirty work?
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
The arrival of more than three million people since World War II has provided a vast labor force. Shows how some of these migrants have struck it rich, but many have been the first to suffer from union neglect and exploitation in low skilled work areas. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

group.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788

results.title: The White Australia Policy
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
Provides a history of Australian working attitudes to non European migration from the first entry restrictions on Chinese in 1885 to the acceptance of Indo-Chinese refugees in the 1970s. This film partoicularly looks at the “White Australia Policy”. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

group.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788

results.title: The Widening net 1945-
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
Covers the period from 1945 to 1985. Shows how the enormous intake of migrants from Britain, Western Europe and the ;Mediterranean alter the face of Australia; and notes how from the early 1970’s, with a changing economy, recruitment fluctuates and then dies down. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

group.title: Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788

results.title: From gaol to gentry
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
This film examines the period of Australian history covering 1788-1840. Depicts the struggle for survival of the first fleet; the transformation of the penal colony into a mecca for British free settlers with the advent of the wool industry; encroachment of the pastoral industry on Aboriginal communities with disastrous results and slowing of migration with economic slump of the 1840’s. Suitable for middle to upper secondary levels.

results.title: The Golden land: 1840s-1900
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Destination Australia: the migrant experience since 1788”.
This film examines the period of Australian history, 1840-1900, that included the Gold-rush years and the farming boom.
